dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A listener, Sarah from Austin, writes in: "I was just reading that Bill Gates sold another huge chunk of his Microsoft stock—like, 1.2 billion dollars after taxes. What's he doing with all that cash?"
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A listener, Sarah from Austin, writes in: I was just reading that Bill Gates sold another huge chunk of his Microsoft stock-like, one point two billion dollars after taxes. What's he doing with all that cash?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After taxes, the billionaire will take home an estimated $2.4 billion. His last large Amazon sell-off occurred in February, when he sold $1.7 billion worth of Amazon stock.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, and it's on top of that three billion dollar sell-off he did back in December, right? It's just staggering.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, and it's on top of that three billion dollar sell-off he did back in December, right? It's just staggering.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: His last large Amazon sell-off occurred in February, when he sold $1.7 billion worth of Amazon stock.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. And you know, Forbes still puts his net worth around ninety billion, but he's actually not the richest person anymore—that's Mark Zuckerberg now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. And you know, Forbes still puts his net worth around ninety billion, but he's actually not the richest person anymore-that's Mark Zuckerberg now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Forbes estimates his net worth at $188.2 billion. He remains the richest person in the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, which is wild to think about. But uh, the reason isn't totally clear for these sales, though we do know some of his past plans.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, which is wild to think about. But uh, the reason isn't totally clear for these sales, though we do know some of his past plans.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is unclear why Bezos is selling these shares.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like back in 2019, he mentioned at a press conference that he'd be selling about five hundred million in shares every year to fund SpaceX.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like back in twenty nineteen, he mentioned at a press conference that he'd be selling about five hundred million in shares every year to fund SpaceX.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2017, the Amazon founder stated at a space conference he would be selling $1 billion worth of shares every year to fund Blue Origin, his space exploration company.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then he's also made these massive pledges, like a billion dollars to the Zuckerberg Day One Fund for animal shelters and preschools.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then he's also made these massive pledges, like a billion dollars to the Zuckerberg Day One Fund for animal shelters and preschools.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He made a $2 billion pledge in September 2018 for the Bezos Day One Fund, which supports nonprofits focused on providing relief for homeless families as well as building a national network of Montessori-inspired preschools.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And nearly three hundred million already given to wildlife preservation since that announcement. Plus, didn't he pledge five billion to cancer research through the Gates Space Fund?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And nearly three hundred million already given to wildlife preservation since that announcement. Plus, didn't he pledge five billion to cancer research through the Gates Space Fund?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since the announcement, Bezos has given away nearly $200 million to homeless-focused nonprofits. He also made a $10 billion pledge in February to the Bezos Earth Fund, dedicated to climate change; no updates have been given since its founding.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and the first funds from that actually went out to hospitals just last month. So it seems like philanthropy is a huge part of it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and the first funds from that actually went out to hospitals just last month. So it seems like philanthropy is a huge part of it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He also made a $10 billion pledge in February to the Bezos Earth Fund, dedicated to climate change; no updates have been given since its founding.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But it's interesting, 'cause this latest sale came right after he testified before the Senate as part of that campaign finance investigation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it's interesting, 'cause this latest sale came right after he testified before the Senate as part of that campaign finance investigation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This latest sell-off comes less than a week after Bezos testified before Congress, via Zoom, as part of an antitrust investigation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Along with Tim Cook and Elon Musk, yeah. Makes you wonder if there's more to the timing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Along with Tim Cook and Elon Musk, yeah. Makes you wonder if there's more to the timing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Facebook founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg, Apple CEO Tim Cook and Google CEO Sundar Pichai also testified.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. And his spokesperson hasn't commented on any of it, which just adds to the mystery.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. And his spokesperson hasn't commented on any of it, which just adds to the mystery.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A spokesperson for Amazon did not respond to requests for comment regarding the sales.

artist_script:
HostA: A listener, Sarah from Austin, writes in: "I was just reading that Bill Gates sold another huge chunk of his Microsoft stock—like, 1.2 billion dollars after taxes. What's he doing with all that cash?"
HostB: Oh yeah, and it's on top of that three billion dollar sell-off he did back in December, right? It's just staggering.
HostA: It really is. And you know, Forbes still puts his net worth around ninety billion, but he's actually not the richest person anymore—that's Mark Zuckerberg now.
HostB: Right, which is wild to think about. But uh, the reason isn't totally clear for these sales, though we do know some of his past plans.
HostA: Yeah, like back in 2019, he mentioned at a press conference that he'd be selling about five hundred million in shares every year to fund SpaceX.
HostB: But then he's also made these massive pledges, like a billion dollars to the Zuckerberg Day One Fund for animal shelters and preschools.
HostA: And nearly three hundred million already given to wildlife preservation since that announcement. Plus, didn't he pledge five billion to cancer research through the Gates Space Fund?
HostB: Yeah, and the first funds from that actually went out to hospitals just last month. So it seems like philanthropy is a huge part of it.
HostA: But it's interesting, 'cause this latest sale came right after he testified before the Senate as part of that campaign finance investigation.
HostB: Along with Tim Cook and Elon Musk, yeah. Makes you wonder if there's more to the timing.
HostA: Definitely. And his spokesperson hasn't commented on any of it, which just adds to the mystery.
